1.09.text:
Have you ever wondered how many countries
there are in the world? While it may seem

4.57.text:
like a fairly straightforward question, it's
actually quite complicated.

8.50.text:
The problem is - it depends on who you ask
as to what answer you get and there is no

12.11.text:
one generally accepted answer. Also, the word
'country' has no official meaning.

16.61.text:
A good place to start might be an organisation
that knows what they're talking about - the

20.99.text:
United Nations.
There are currently 193 members of the UN.

25.33.text:
This is why this is the lowest number you'll
ever hear to how many countries there are.

29.52.text:
Along with the 193 members, the UN also has
two permanent non-member observer states - the

34.45.text:
Holy See (representing the Vatican City State),
and the State of Palestine. Despite not being

39.30.text:
a member, the Vatican City is a country and
is recognised by everyone as such.

43.83.text:
Despite being a country within a city within
a country and small not only by country or

48.21.text:
city standards but more comparable in size
to that of a small village with a population

52.19.text:
of around 800 and a land area of less than
half a square kilometre. It is officially

56.83.text:
the smallest country in the world and compared
to the largest country, it is 38 million times

61.11.text:
smaller than Russia.
But size doesn't matter and the fact of the

64.97.text:
matter is the Vatican City is a country. So...
logic would dictate that the State of Palestine

70.13.text:
is also a country then, right? Well... no.
Not yet anyway.

75.34.text:
The State of Palestine wants to be a full
member of the UN and submitted an application

79.51.text:
is November of 2011. However, the only reason
the Holy See isn't a full simply because...

84.59.text:
it doesn't want to be. Possibly because it
wants to remain neutral.

88.42.text:
It seems unlikely that Palestine will gain
full membership for one reason - the United

93.18.text:
States of America.
If you're unaware of the situation in the

96.46.text:
Middle East, the Palestinians and the Israelis
have waging war on and off for decades.

100.48.text:
And with Israel being of close ally of the
United States, who often provide financial

104.45.text:
and military assistance to Israel, the US
has always voted against Palestine. This is

108.90.text:
despite president Obama saying he does want
a sovereign Palestinian state.

113.27.text:
The US didn't want Palestine to even become
an observer state, but they still won an overwhelming

117.42.text:
majority. However, in order to gain full membership,
the decision lies with the UN Security Council.

124.09.text:
The Security Council is made of 15 members
- 5 permanent members (also known as The Big

128.26.text:
Five), and 10 non-permanent members who serve
for 2 years. To become a full member of the

133.17.text:
UN a country must obtain a two-thirds majority
vote.

136.29.text:
The Big Five consists of - China, Russia,
France, the United States, and the United

140.97.text:
Kingdom, all of whom has what's known as 'veto
power' in which they can veto any UN resolution

145.83.text:
and it won't get passed, even if all other
14 members are in favour of it. Therefore,

150.81.text:
the US can veto any membership application
made by the State of Palestine.

154.69.text:
The UN aside, there are others reasons why
you might hesitate to call Palestine a country.

158.58.text:
First of all, they don't actually have any
legally defined borders and the lines used

163.23.text:
to outline their claimed territories of the
West Bank and the Gaza strip are actually

167.07.text:
lines created in 1949 as part of an armistice
agreement to end of the violence of the Arab-Israeli

171.74.text:
war and were never intended to be used as
internal borders.

175.22.text:
On top of this, the Israeli army control huge
parts of their land, although this is widely

180.01.text:
considered by the entire international community
as a breach of international law.

185.32.text:
Moving on, the US Department of State list
195 independent countries, and these are...

190.54.text:
the 193 members of the UN, the previously
discussed Vatican City, as well as... the

194.76.text:
Republic of Kosovo.
Kosovo is a partially recognised country in

198.33.text:
Eastern Europe that declared its independence
from Serbia in 2008. However, Serbia rejects

203.31.text:
their independence and claims that Kosovo
is a province of Serbia.

206.41.text:
Currently, 100 out of the 193 UN members recognise
Kosovo as a country according to kosovothanksyou.com,

212.03.text:
a website that thanks every country for recognising
them in their native language.

218.50.text:
Kosovo hasn't made a application for UN membership.
This is because the UN Security Council is

223.55.text:
split on the issue of Kosovo independence.
While the UK, the US and France all recogsnise

228.63.text:
Kosovo and have diplomatic relations with
them, Russia and China do not. If all five

233.03.text:
were asked 'is Kosovo a country?', you would
get a variety of different responses but suffice

237.11.text:
to say the resolution would not get passed.
Now, according to a website I use quite a

242.34.text:
lot, about.com, there are 196 countries. They
list the same 195 as the US Department of

248.28.text:
State, plus one more - Taiwan.
The situation with Taiwan is an incredibly

253.76.text:
complex one that basically boils down to whether
Taiwan is its own country, or part of China.

258.03.text:
While it is officially officially considered
part of China by the UN, it effectively operates

262.37.text:
as its own country and China have no jurisdiction
on the island.

266.34.text:
Taiwan's official name, by the way, is the
Republic of China, not to be confused with

270.65.text:
the PEOPLE'S Republic of China, or as they're
more commonly know, well... China.

276.56.text:
To fully understand the situation we need
to go all the way back to 1895 when the Japanese

280.81.text:
Empire took control of the island of Taiwan
from Qing Dynasty.

284.02.text:
After the fall of the Dynasty in the early
20th century, the Republic of China was established

288.56.text:
in 1912 and the Nationalist Party were elected
government.

291.97.text:
In 1921, the Communist Party of China was
founded with very different ideological views,

296.56.text:
and in 1927 the Chinese Civil War began between
the Nationalists and the Communists.

300.78.text:
Japan took the civil war as an opportunity
to invade China in 1931. For years the civil

305.40.text:
war continued until 1937 when Japan began
a full-scale invasion of China and took control

310.37.text:
of the city of Beijing. The civil war were
temporarily put on hold so China could defend

314.80.text:
its land from the Japanese.
In 1941, Japan bombed Pearl Harbor, causing

319.61.text:
immediate declaration of war on Japan by the
United States and began their involvement

323.50.text:
in World War II.
In August 1945, the United States dropped

327.15.text:
atomic bombs on the Japanese cities of Hiroshima
and Nagasaki.

330.47.text:
The Allied Forces then issued Japan a surrender
ultimatum: the Potsdam Declaration. The agreement

336.33.text:
stated, among other things, that Japan must
relinquish control of land that they had acquired

340.02.text:
via force, and this included the island of
Taiwan obtained 50 years previously from the

344.70.text:
Qing Dynasty.
The Allies gave two choices to Japan - an

347.45.text:
unconditional surrender, or face (and I quote)
"prompt and utter destruction".

352.73.text:
On September 2nd 1945 Japan signed the agreement
which put an ended to the 2nd World War.

357.69.text:
Sovereignty of Taiwan was therefore handed
over to the Republic of China.

362.34.text:
Later that year, the United Nations was founded
with the Republic of China as one its founding

365.88.text:
members and one of the permanent members of
the Security Council.

369.32.text:
The original Big Five were effectively the
same as today, except with the Republic of

372.59.text:
China and the Soviet Union instead of the
People's Republic of China and the Russian

375.85.text:
Federation respectively.
So... one year later and Chinese Civil War

380.44.text:
started up again. This time around, the Communist
forces completely overwhelmed the Nationalist

384.79.text:
forces and in 1949, the Communist Part had
total control of the mainland, forcing the

390.27.text:
Nationalists to retreat to the island of Taiwan.
This effectively ended the civil war and lead

394.52.text:
to the creation of the People's Republic of
China, by the Communist Party.

398.88.text:
This then created an incredibly complicated
situation in which there were effectively

403.11.text:
two Chinas, both claiming the exact same land:
the whole of China.

409.08.text:
The People's Republic of China controlled
the mainland, while the Republic of China

412.30.text:
controlled Taiwan, but both claimed each others
land. Things remained like this for two decades

417.20.text:
while the Republic of China continued to represent
China at the UN.

421.30.text:
This was until 1971 when the UN General Assembly
voted to replace the Republic of China with

426.05.text:
the People's Republic of China as China's
sole representative, including Taiwan, despite

430.54.text:
them never having any jurisdiction on the
island in their history.

434.93.text:
In 1991, the Republic of China opted for a
different approach and applied for UN membership

439.63.text:
under the name 'the Republic of Taiwan'. Taiwan
repeatedly re-applied but with China's veto

444.79.text:
power, realistically, it was never going to
happen.

447.26.text:
The current president of Taiwan, however,
does not want independence, and said in his

451.56.text:
inaugural address - "no reunification, no
independence, no war". However has since said

457.27.text:
that actually he DOES want unification with
China.

460.79.text:
Relations between the Chinese and Taiwanese
presidents is good, they both agree Taiwan

464.13.text:
should not be an independent country, they
both adhere to the one-China policy, unfortunately,

468.35.text:
they still can't agree on who actually has
sovereignty over China.

471.84.text:
Still, Taiwan is pretty much like any country
- they have their own passports, their own

476.43.text:
president, their own government, their own
military, they even take part in sporting

479.80.text:
events such as the Olympics and the FIFA World
Cup, albeit under the pseudonym 'Chinese Taipei',

485.23.text:
to keep China happy. Taipei being the capital
of Taiwan.

487.57.text:
So while very few countries officially recognise
Taiwan as a country or the Republic of China

491.67.text:
as the legitimate government of all of China,
most countries do recognise Taiwan unofficially

495.60.text:
and have Taiwan Embassies in their country.
Countries tend to avoid officially recognising

501.25.text:
Taiwan as a country as it pisses off China.
This is the reason why the US Department of

505.46.text:
State list 195 countries and excluded Taiwan,
because the United States really wouldn't

511.00.text:
want to piss of China, for uh... let's just
say political reasons....

515.92.text:
So... everyone clear on the situation with
Taiwan? No? Well, no-one really is but let's

523.93.text:
move on...
To the place where I live: the United Kingdom.

528.10.text:
More specifically Scotland but it's the United
Kingdom I want to talk about. The United Kingdom

532.37.text:
is generally referred to as a "country of
countries" consisting of: Scotland, England,

536.75.text:
Wales, and Northern Ireland.
So... is the United Kingdom one country...

541.27.text:
or four countries?
Well, first of all, it's actually a misconception

545.71.text:
that there are four countries in the UK. There's
actually only three.

549.57.text:
See, while Scotland and England both have
a history of being independent countries,

553.65.text:
and Wales is a little more complicated as
it was previously considered a principality,

557.56.text:
but is now a country, Northern Ireland is
not, nor has it ever been, a country. Northern

562.65.text:
Ireland is technically considered a province
of the United Kingdom.

566.91.text:
This newsletter from the International Organisation
for Standardisation clearly lists Northern

570.95.text:
Ireland as a province, as well as the status
of Wales being upgraded from principality

574.94.text:
to country. Although it could be argued the
principality of Wales ended in 1542 and that

580.36.text:
Wales has been a country for centuries.
A very brief British history lesson...

585.64.text:
In 1707, the Kingdom of Scotland and the Kingdom
of England (which included Wales) joined to

589.39.text:
create the Kingdom of Great Britain. In 1801,
the Kingdom of Ireland joined to create the

593.47.text:
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
Then, in 1922, after the Irish War of Independence

599.10.text:
Ireland succeeded from Britain and formed
the Republic of Ireland.

601.81.text:
Believe it or not, very briefly, the whole
island of Ireland succeeded from Britain,

606.72.text:
but Northern Ireland quickly and expectedly
re-joined to create the United Kingdom of

610.50.text:
Great Britain and Northern Ireland. Which
is what it's known as today.

614.19.text:
So, Northern Ireland was part of Ireland and
is now part of the UK, but has been a country

618.76.text:
in its own right. Northern Ireland doesn't
even have its own official flag!

622.45.text:
The St. Patrick's solitaire is sometimes used
unofficially to distinguish Northern Ireland

626.70.text:
from the rest of the UK. The Ulster Banner
is also used and is the flag that FIFA use

631.58.text:
to represent their national football team.
But the one and only flag that is used officially

637.63.text:
is... the Union Jack.
So, the UK is made up of three countries and

641.80.text:
one province. And while the three countries
are not independent countries or sovereign

645.86.text:
states, they are still countries.
The term for a country within a country is

649.62.text:
a "constituent country" and is not unique
to the UK.

652.83.text:
The Netherlands is constituent country with
the Kingdom of the Netherlands, which contains

657.44.text:
three other countries: Aruba, Curacao, and
Sint Maartin.

661.35.text:
The Netherlands is in Europe, while the other
three are island countries in the Caribbean

664.59.text:
some 5000 miles away.
To further complicate matters, the Netherlands

668.95.text:
is made up of 12 provinces in Europe, as well
as three special municipalities - also in

674.49.text:
the Caribbean. These are: Bonaire, St. Eustatius,
and Saba, collectively referred to as the

679.64.text:
Caribbean Netherlands. And the term Dutch
Caribbean is used to refer to all of the Caribbean

683.74.text:
islands within the kingdom of the Netherlands.
All 4 countries within the Kingdom are considered

688.09.text:
equal, but in reality, 98% of both the population
and the land area of the within the 12 European

693.47.text:
provinces.
Another example would be the Kingdom of Denmark,

696.69.text:
which holds sovereignty of the two autonomous
countries of Greenland and the Faroe Islands.

700.52.text:
Greenland being the world's largest island
that's not a continent and the Faroe Islands

703.64.text:
are a small archipelago north of Scotland.
But despite Greenland being over 1500 times

708.70.text:
the size of the Faroe Islands, they both have
similar populations of around 50,000.

712.96.text:
There's also French Polynesia, which is an
overseas country of the French Republic, made

716.59.text:
up of several islands in the South Pacific,
most notable of which is the island of Tahiti.

721.83.text:
Then we come to a slightly more complicated
situation with New Zealand and the countries

725.07.text:
of Niue and the Cook Islands who are in a
agreement known as free association.

728.83.text:
There are only three other countries in the
world under free association, and they are:

733.42.text:
the Marshall Islands, the Federated States
of Micronesia, and Palau. All in free association

737.77.text:
with the United States.
The major difference is that all three of

740.91.text:
these countries are members of the UN while
Niue and the Cook Islands are not.

745.48.text:
Freely associated states can either be thought
of as independent or not, or even... both?

750.38.text:
It's kind of like a Schrodinger's cat situation
in which the cat can be thought of as both

755.21.text:
dead and alive simultaneously.
Niue and the Cook Islands can be considered

759.56.text:
independent or not simultaneously, so we can
call these two.... Schrodinger's countries.

764.65.text:
And finally, we come to a category of countries
(and I use the term loosely), that have received

768.88.text:
little or no recognition. One example would
be Somaliland, part of Somalia that has declared

773.58.text:
itself an independent country but thus far
received absolutely no recognition whatever

778.23.text:
ever... from any country, UN member or otherwise.
Of course there are other examples, all of

784.66.text:
whom have received at least some recognition,
albeit extremely limited, and in some cases,

789.21.text:
not by any UN members.
External recognition is a key attribute to

793.69.text:
considered a country and therefore it would
be a bit of a stretch to call any of them

796.99.text:
countries at the moment.
So... how many countries are there in the

800.27.text:
world? Well, there really are no right or
answers. Well, I mean, there are wrong answers...

806.97.text:
five... for example, is a wrong answer.
But because of the ambiguity of the word 'country',

812.22.text:
there isn't one generally accepted answer.
Hopefully you understand that the point of

816.86.text:
this video is that I provided you with the
necessary information, so that you could apply your

820.58.text:
own judgement to get the answer.
But if you really want some numbers, some

825.15.text:
possible answers would be...
Just the members of the UN, counting the Vatican

829.04.text:
City since it's also a country, counting Kosovo
- the most recognised country not in the UN,

834.33.text: counting Taiwan - the unofficial country, counting the State of Palestine - the UN observer

838.64.text:
state, then we could count the unrecognised
countries, the constituent countries, and

842.80.text: Niue and the Cook Islands. Then things could get a bit out of hand and we could start calling everything a country.

848.39.text:
For example: Hong Kong, Puerto Rico and Bermuda. None
of which are countries but given the dictionary

853.47.text:
definition it wouldn't seem too far-fetched
to call them countries.

856.52.text:
Then we could come up with a near infinite
number of answers depending on how you apply

860.55.text:
the use of the word 'country'. But it seems
that the most widely accepted answer is 196.

867.13.text:
But it's important that you understand the
answer of 196 so that if something changes

870.78.text:
you can adjust the number accordingly, or
not.

874.32.text:
For example, if Kosovo hypothetically became
the 194th member of the UN, there would still

879.35.text:
be 196 countries, but if you used 194 as your
answer then you would need to add one.

885.87.text:
An important note to is that everything in
this video is correct at the time it was uploaded

889.66.text: in late June of 2013, and things may have changed depending on when you're watching this.

894.16.text:
Well, thank you very much for watching my
very first YouTube video, and be sure to subscribe

898.64.text: as I've got dozens more ideas for videos that I can't wait to start making. Thanks again!
